abstract.p: Tom Cornwell letter corrects errors in Victor Navasky's May 28 review of Maurice Isserman's biography of Michael Harrington

block.p: Victor Navasky's perceptive review of Maurice Isserman's well-researched and rivetingly written biography of Michael Harrington, ''The Other American'' (May 28), contains three errors of fact. The Catholic Worker movement grew out of the Catholic Worker paper (of which I am a 47-year veteran), not vice versa. The circulation of The Catholic Worker was not 5,000 when Michael was with the movement in the early 1950's, but 50,000. (It is 90,000 now.) Liberation magazine was a monthly, not a quarterly.

Victor Navasky's perceptive review of Maurice Isserman's well-researched and rivetingly written biography of Michael Harrington, ''The Other American'' (May 28), contains three errors of fact. The Catholic Worker movement grew out of the Catholic Worker paper (of which I am a 47-year veteran), not vice versa. The circulation of The Catholic Worker was not 5,000 when Michael was with the movement in the early 1950's, but 50,000. (It is 90,000 now.) Liberation magazine was a monthly, not a quarterly.

Michael Harrington was a tragic figure in a tragic time, as the American dream became a nightmare. What is possible in ''this lousy rotten system'' (Dorothy Day's words) is still lousy and rotten. To live a revolution requires faith. Faith in humankind unaided by grace after Hitler, Stalin and Pol Pot takes a farther leap than faith in God.
